sentences: Theodore Edwin White (born February 4, 1938) is a Hugo Award-winning American science fiction writer, editor and fan, as well as a music critic.
section: N/A

sentences: He writes and edits as Ted White.
section: N/A

sentences: In addition to books and stories written under his own name, he has also co-authored novels with Dave van Arnam as Ron Archer, and with Terry Carr as Norman Edwards.
section: N/A

sentences: == Author, editor, critic and DJ ==
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ ==

sentences: === Fandom origins ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: Since the time he was a teenager, White has been a prolific contributor to science fiction fanzines, and in 1968 he won the Hugo Award for Best Fan Writer.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: His skill as an essayist is evident in "The Bet", a memoir of a tense day in 1960 when a dispute over a record owned by music critic Linda Solomon prompted fellow science fiction writer Harlan Ellison to bet his entire record collection against a single record in White's collection, and then renege on the deal.Despite his considerable professional credits, White maintains that his achievements in fandom mean more to him than anything else he has done.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: In 1953, he edited and published  Zip, the first of many fanzines he published over the following decades.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: In 1956â€“57, he co-edited Stellar with Larry Stark, followed by Void when he joined the founding editors, Gregory Benford and James Benford (1960), Minac, Egoboo and others.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: In addition to helping others publish their own fanzines, he was a regular columnist in Yandro and Richard E. Geis' Psychotic/SF Review.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: He also has been active in numerous fan events, such as organizing the 1967 World Science Fiction Convention in New York as co-chairman.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: As of 2018, he was still active on several of the fandom- and fanzine-oriented electronic mailing lists.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fandom origins ===

sentences: === Radio ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Radio ===

sentences: From 1977 into 1979, as Dr. Progresso, he did the Friday afternoon Dr. Progresso radio show on WGTB-FM (90.1).
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Radio ===

sentences: === Music critic ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: In 1959, at the age of 21, White moved from Falls Church, Virginia, to New York City with his first wife, Sylvia Dees White.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: That year, he began writing music criticism for Metronome and a column for Tom Wilson's Jazz Guide (later 33 Guide).
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: As a music critic, he expanded into jazz writing and journalism for Rogue, along with LP liner notes, concert reviews and interviews.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: He was the only person to record an interview with Eric Dolphy (who died in 1964).
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: Moving online, White became the music editor of the Collecting Channel [1] website in 1999, and he maintains his own website of music commentary under his Dr. Progresso pseudonym.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Music critic ===

sentences: === Science fiction author ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: "Phoenix", a 1963 collaboration with Marion Zimmer Bradley, was White's first professionally published story, which he later expanded into the novel Phoenix Prime, beginning the Qanar series of books.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: His first novel, Invasion from 2500 (1964), was written in collaboration with Terry Carr under the pseudonym Norman Edwards.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: Between 1964 and 1978 he wrote two science fiction series and 11 standalone novels, including one Captain America novel.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: Two of the novels were written in collaboration with Dave van Arnam, one with David Bischoff and one, using White's Doc Phoenix character, with Marv Wolfman.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: White was a 1966 Nebula nominee for his short story, "The Peacock King," written with Larry McCombs.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: He was also instrumental in kick-starting the professional careers of other writers, notably Lee Hoffman.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Science fiction author ===

sentences: === Fiction editor ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: White held the position of assistant editor at The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction from 1963 to 1968.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: From October 1968 until October 1978, he edited Amazing Stories and Fantastic, upgrading the quality of the fiction while showcasing a variety of talented illustrators.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: He also edited two 1973 anthologies, The Best from Amazing Stories and The Best from Fantastic.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: His reputation as an editor impressed the publishers of Heavy Metal who hired him to introduce non-fiction and prose fiction into the magazine which featured mainly graphic stories until White's arrival in 1979.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: In 1985, he was an associate editor of the magazine Stardate.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Fiction editor ===

sentences: === Musician ===
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Musician ===

sentences: Ted also plays keyboards and saxophone.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Musician ===

sentences: Currently, he performs with the Washington, DC area improvisational group Conduit.
section: == Author, editor, critic and DJ == | === Musician ===
